rsbNotes.title: Ps 104
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 104 God’s great act of creation is emphasized, reflecting the teaching and vocabulary of Gen. 1. Parallels may be observed between this song and an Egyptian hymn of Amenhotep IV (Akhenaton) to the sun. But the psalm affirms that the Creator alone, and not any aspect of creation, such as the sun, should be worshiped.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:1
rsbNotes.text:
104:1 O my soul. See comment on Ps. 103:1.

You are clothed. This section develops the metaphor of the creation as God’s garment. This emphasizes the distinction between the Creator and the creation and implicitly disparages worship of any aspect of the creation, however glorious it may seem (Rom. 1:22).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:2
rsbNotes.text:
104:2 with light. A reference to the first day of creation (Gen. 1:3).

the heavens. The second day of creation (Gen. 1:6–8).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:3
rsbNotes.text: 104:3 the wings of the wind. See 18:9 and note.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:4
rsbNotes.text: 104:4 a flaming fire. God’s heavenly servants have an awesome appearance. How much more powerful must God, their Creator, be. This verse may be a polemic against Baal worship, since Canaanite mythological texts describe the servants of their god as flames of fire.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:5
rsbNotes.text: 104:5 should never be moved. The world is stable and ordered, not chaotic. God’s control of the world is comforting to those who recognize it. See “God the Creator” at 148:5.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:6
rsbNotes.text: 104:6 the waters. God created the waters and ordered them in rivers, lakes, and oceans. In the religions of the surrounding nations, the sea is a symbol of chaos and disorder. Their pantheistic theology deifies the sea and sets it against the gods of order. The Bible uses this imagery, but disallows the polytheistic theology (Ps. 18:4; 46:2, 3; 74:13–15; Nah. 1).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:9
rsbNotes.text: 104:9 might not again cover. A reference to the promise God made to Noah after the Flood (Gen. 9:11).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:14
rsbNotes.text: 104:14 You cause the grass to grow. A reflection of the third day of creation (Gen. 1:9–13).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:15
rsbNotes.text: 104:15 wine to gladden the heart of man. God’s kindness is exhibited in His provisions for daily life (Acts 14:17; 1 Tim. 4:3, 4).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:19
rsbNotes.text: 104:19 the moon . . . the sun. See Gen. 1:14–19—the fourth day of creation.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:21
rsbNotes.text: 104:21 from God. What appears to be purely natural—lions seeking their prey—is an act of providence.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 104:23
rsbNotes.text: 104:23 Man goes out. God has given His creation a wonderfully ordered rhythm.
